attributes.title: Attractiveness of a broader range of TVT tariffs and their marketing

q1.value: Attractiveness of a broader range of TVT tariffs and their marketing

q2.value: Gesche Margarethe Huebner | Moira Nicolson | Michael Fell

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Time-varying tariffs where electricity costs differently depending on time of day (or day) are considered as essential to reduce carbon emissions. However, at least in the UK, they are not commercially available yet and research is limited on what tariff designs are most attractive to consumers and what could boost attractiveness. Using a nationally representative survey (N = 3000 British energy bill payers), we will aim at addressing the following under-researched areas in five experiments: • Attractiveness of a broader range of TVT tariffs (time-varying tariffs) (e.g., peak rebates, “inverted” TOU rates) • Reconciling the findings of conflicting research on consumer preferences • The attractiveness of tools for transitioning to TVTs (e.g., bill protection)

q16.value: Relative attractiveness of different TVTs: This experiment tests the attractiveness of five TVTs: a static time-of-use (TOU) tariff, an inverted TOU tariff, critical peak pricing (CPP), critical peak rebate (CPR), real time pricing (RT). Participants are assigned randomly to one of the five groups (ngroup ~ 600). They see a description of the respective tariff and are then presented with three response options: switching to tariff, switching to a flat rate tariff, staying on their current tariff. Marketing experiment: Testing whether variations of the detail which a tariff was presented with impacted on switching behaviour. Participants will see one of six tariff descriptions, five of which have the same pricing structure, a three-tiered TOU tariff, but are presented in different ways to test if specific variations are particularly effective in securing sign-up, or work particularly well for subgroups. The sixth group sees a flat rate to assess willingness to switch to a non-TVT as a comparison baseline. CPR experiment: In this experiment, participants are presented with one of five variations on how the rebate would be delivered to them under a CPR tariff if they successfully reduce their energy consumption on at least 10 days where a critical event was called . Thermostat experiment: The control group will be shown a message stating that their present electricity supplier has offer, called Direct Savers, in which the participant would receive a free smart thermostat to control their heating via a smartphone or computer. The supplier could turn the heating up or down for short periods with an effect up to 1 degree Celsius which can be overriden at any time (small temperature change, full override). Participants are asked to indicate whether they take up this offer or not in all conditions. The control condition will be contrasted with two other sets of conditions with two different research questions in mind. (1) To test the effect of choice. Instead of being given a specific thermostat, the participant can choose between three thermostats. The hypothesis is that having choice will increase uptake rate. (2) To test the effect of overrides and magnitude of temperature change. Trust experiment: Participants will see one of four descriptions about their energy supplier, and then have to rate their trust in their energy supplier. In the control condition, it only reminds participants that they had previously indicated who their supplier is. The second groups sees a message stating that their energy supplier is considering to introduce time of use tariffs, the third group sees the same but with the added information that government encourages energy suppliers to do, and in the fourth group it says that consumer organizations encourage energy suppliers to do so.

q17.value: We will mainly use logistic regression given the outcome variable is switching to the TVT / the offer or not. For one analysis, ANOVA is used. In some analyses, we are only interested in the effect of the predictor; in others, we will control for household- and house variables, and psychological constructs.

registration_responses.q1: Attractiveness of a broader range of TVT tariffs and their marketing
registration_responses.q2: Gesche Margarethe Huebner | Moira Nicolson | Michael Fell

attributes.title: When Do Elected Officials Help Immigrants Become Citizens? A Field Experiment in Germany

q1.value: When Do Elected Officials Help Immigrants Become Citizens? A Field Experiment in Germany

q2.value: Jeyhun Alizade | Rafaela Dancygier | Ruth Ditlmann

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Second experiment in a correspondence study in which emails are sent to German local politicians by putative immigrants requesting help in the naturalization process.

q16.value: We test whether response rates vary by three email characteristics: sender nationality (Turkish vs. Canadian); electoral incentives prime; need for integration prime. We also hypothesize heterogeneous treatment effects by municipality characteristics and politician partisanship.

q17.value: Probit/Logit and OLS regressions. Main dependent variable of interest is whether a politician responded.

q25.value: The latest date of approval was 3/28/2017.

registration_responses.q1: When Do Elected Officials Help Immigrants Become Citizens? A Field Experiment in Germany
registration_responses.q2: Jeyhun Alizade | Rafaela Dancygier | Ruth Ditlmann

We also hypothesize heterogeneous treatment effects by municipality characteristics and politician partisanship.

attributes.title: Ethnic and Religious Discrimination and the Role of Soft Information – Field Experimental Evidence from the Danish Labor Market

q1.value: Ethnic and Religious Discrimination and the Role of Soft Information – Field Experimental Evidence from the Danish Labor Market

q5.value: The Danish Institute for Human Rights

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This research project examines differential treatment in the hiring process related to applicants' ethnic and religious affiliation. Further, the project sheds light on the role of soft information—information related to the applicants’ endorsement of Danish/Western norms—provided in job applications.

q16.value: H1: Applicants with Middle Eastern-sounding names receive less callbacks compared to equally qualified applicants with Danish-sounding names. H2: Applicants with Middle Eastern-sounding names wearing a headscarf receive less callbacks compared to applicants with Middle Eastern-sounding names not wearing a headscarf. H3: An increase of soft information in the application lowers the gap between applicants with Danish-sounding names and applicants with Middle Eastern-sounding names. H4: Having a Danish-sounding socioeconomic low status names has no effect on the chances of receiving a callback.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested by conducting a correspondence test. By answering real job ads with fictitious application templates, it is possible to hold everything equal except applicants' ethnic or religious affiliation.

registration_responses.q1: Ethnic and Religious Discrimination and the Role of Soft Information – Field Experimental Evidence from the Danish Labor Market
registration_responses.q5: The Danish Institute for Human Rights

H3: An increase of soft information in the application lowers the gap between applicants with Danish-sounding names and applicants with Middle Eastern-sounding names. H4: Having a Danish-sounding socioeconomic low status names has no effect on the chances of receiving a callback.

attributes.title: Behavioral interventions to enhance housing tax compliance: randomized field experiment in China

q1.value: Behavioral interventions to enhance housing tax compliance: randomized field experiment in China

q2.value: Fangwen Lu | Zhixin Dai | Kezhi Wang

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Shanghai is one of the Chinese cities that pilot housing tax. Housing tax is paid once a year and is due at the end of the year. Over the past years, the tax authority sent SMS multiple times to remind the relevant taxpayers. We propose to the tax authority to experiment with various information interventions and explore the effectiveness.

q16.value: The experiment will include two sets of interventions. One set is on monitoring and punishing, and the other is on correcting behavioral bias. Monitoring and punishing: Basic message: it mainly reminds the deadline is 12/31/2018. Personalized: it additionally provides info on the specific house address and the amount of tax. Punishing: on the top of the basic message, it additionally emphasizes the severity of the punishment related to late fee, personal credit, etc. Personalized + Punishing: combination of monitoring and punishing. Correcting behavioral bias: Correcting projection bias: it mentions the usual projection bias and the consequence of missing the deadline, and then urge immediate action. Correcting procrastination: it mentions the usual procrastination and the consequence of missing the deadline, and then urge immediate action. The overall design is a cross-cutting design with 4*3 (12) intervention combinations and an additional group receiving no message. The hypotheses are as follows. Is the message effective comparing to the no-message situation? Are the personalized message and the punishing message more effective comparing to the basic message? Do the personalized message and the punishing message have interacting effect? Are the two correcting-bias interventions effective? Are the above-mentioned effects heterogeneous among various types of payers?

q17.value: The hypothesis would be estimated using OLS regression techniques. We will construct dummy variables representing each intervention or intervention combination. For the heterogeneous effects, we will either do regressions by subgroups or using the interactions. The dependent variables will be whether the taxpayer paid the housing tax within various time intervals from the date of message sending to January 2019.

q19.value: About 200000 taxpayers with the possibility of adding more potential taxpayers.

registration_responses.q1: Behavioral interventions to enhance housing tax compliance: randomized field experiment in China

Do the personalized message and the punishing message have interacting effect? Are the two correcting-bias interventions effective? The dependent variables will be whether the taxpayer paid the housing tax within various time intervals from the date of message sending to January 2019.

attributes.title: Can trust be built through citizen monitoring of police activity?

q1.value: Can trust be built through citizen monitoring of police activity?

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: New technologies can improve oversight, management of police and, through this process, enhance public confidence and gain citizens’ trust. In this project, we study the effects of two programs that make use of new technologies to improve the interaction between the police and citizens in the state of Santa Catarina, Brazil. More specifically, we evaluate the effects of: i) the Rede de Vizinhos (“Neighbor network”) community policing program, through which citizens exchange real-time information about crime and public safety through dedicated WhatsApp instant messages groups with the participation of a police officer; and ii) the introduction of police body-worn cameras on use of force and citizen’s complaints. (see Pre-Analysis Plan for more details)

q16.value: Primary Outcome Family 1: Security of Life and Property 1a. Negative effect on incidence of crime 1b. Positive effect on perceptions of safety (personal, land, and possessions) Primary Outcome Family 2: Citizen Perceptions of the Police 2. Positive effect on citizen perceptions of police Primary Outcome Family 3: Police Perceptions of and Behaviors Toward Citizens 3a. Positive effect on perceptions of police empathy, accountability, and abuse and corruption concerns 3b. Negative effect reporting of police abuse and bribery Primary Outcome Family 4: Behavioral Cooperation of Citizens with the Police 4a. Positive effect on reporting of crime victimization 4b. Positive effect on reporting of crime prevention tips 4c. Positive effect on reporting of victimization by the police Mechanism Family 1: Perceived Costs to Citizens Cooperating with the Police M1a. Positive effect on beliefs about police intentions M1b. Positive effect on knowledge of criminal justice system M1c. Positive effect on norms of citizens cooperation with police Mechanism Family 2: Perceived Returns to Citizens Cooperating with the Police M2a. Positive effect on beliefs about police capacity M2b. Positive effect on perceptions of responsiveness to citizen feedback Secondary Outcome Family 1: Trust in the State S1. Positive effect on trust in the state Secondary Outcome Family 2: Communal Trust S2. Positive effect on communal trust Compliance with Treatment: Citizen Interactions with Police C. Positive effect on rate of citizen interactions with police

q17.value: Rede de Vizinhos: we conduct an experiment, inducing take-up in RdV in randomly-selected neighborhoods across the state through a targeted information campaign through Facebook. The aim is to assess the effect of the program on crime, on the efficiency of police response and on the public perception of safety and police activity. Body-worn cameras: we conduct a randomized implementation of body-worn cameras (BWC). To this end, we will work in collaboration with PMSC to randomly assign BWCs across police officers and implement randomly-selected shifts where it will be unavailable for all officers within police stations. (see Pre-Analysis Plan for more details)

q19.value: Rede de Vizinhos: 125 neighborhoods across 15 municipalities, survey conducted in 3,300 households. CopCast: 445 police officers

q27.value: Polícia Militar de Santa Catarina, Igarapé Institute

attributes.title: The Impact of an extended Cooling-off Period in the Consumer Finance Market

q1.value: The Impact of an extended Cooling-off Period in the Consumer Finance Market

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Cooling-off periods are a widely implemented consumer protection measure for decisions that individuals face infrequently and that could be influenced by impulsive behavior. Financial contracts face in many countries cooling-off periods that give consumers the option to reconsider the contract and cancel it if they regret the signing of a contract. The rationale for the regulation is mainly based on evidence in behavioral economics, that argues that a cooling-off period helps to protect individuals from taking impulsive, time-inconsistent decisions. Little empirical evidence exists on the use of the cooling-off period for financial products as well as on the influence of the length of the cooling-off period. Based on an administrative dataset provided by consumer finance banks, this project plans to provide descriptive evidence on the use of the cooling-off period in the consumer finance market in Switzerland. The unique setting further allows to study a regulatory change that increased the period from 7 to 14 days in a quasi-experimental setting.

q16.value: The hypotheses refer to the analysis of the extension of the cooling-off period. The hypotheses tested refer to two main outcome variables: Withdrawal and cancelation of cash credit offers. Hypotheses related to contract withdrawal A. The extended cooling-off period may decrease the propensity to withdraw a loan offer. Hypotheses related to contract cancelation A. The extended cooling-off period may have a positive average treatment effect on the propensity to make use of the option to cancel a contract. B. If there is a positive treatment effect, the effect might be mainly observed 1 for consumers who tend to consume impulsively. 2 for consumers who actively shop around for better offers. 3 for consumers whose planned purchase requires fast access to liquidity and for whom the prolonged waiting period until the amount is disbursed made the purchase more difficult.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using mainly difference in differences settings. The pre-analysis plan provides an outline of the applied empirical strategy.

q27.value: The study focuses on the impact of a regulatory change

attributes.title: Party Persuasion about Gun Policy (Exp. 2 - 2016 CCES Survey Experiments)

q1.value: Party Persuasion about Gun Policy (Exp. 2 - 2016 CCES Survey Experiments)

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This survey experiment tests the influence of US Congressional party leaders on attitudes about gun regulation policy. The treatments use hypothetical statements from the Democratic and Republican leaders of the US Senate with randomly assigned elements to test the influence of partisan affiliation and gun regulation policy positions that are consistent with or contrary to the Republican and Democratic parties. The survey experiment is embedded in the post-election wave of the University of Miami module of the 2016 Cooperative Congressional Election Study.

q16.value: Outcomes 1) Reduction in gun related deaths – two outcomes with opposing policy pre-disposition phrasing a) Pro-regulation phrasing: stricter laws lead to fewer deaths i) Mean on four point response scale (omit skip, not asked) ii) Dummy for Big (1) or Some (2) reduction in deaths (Big/Some = 1; Little/No = 0) b) Pro-ownership phrasing: more ownership leads to fewer deaths i) Mean on four point response scale (omit skip, not asked) ii) Dummy for Big (1) or Some (2) reduction in deaths (Big/Some = 1; Little/No = 0) c) Note: this was supposed to be a pre-post difference measure… but I screwed up the instructions to YouGov so the pre-question and post-question were independently randomly assigned. i) Pre-test was the beginning of the pre-election wave ii) Since the questions have different valences, pre-post is only possible for half of each experiment, and therefore dropped 2) Universal background checks a) Dummy for “support” in MIA403a (dichotomous choice = support/oppose) b) Change from Common Content pre-election (CC16_330a) o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA403a 3) Easy concealed carry permit a) Dummy for “oppose” in MIA403b (dichotomous choice = support/oppose) o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA403b b) Change from Common Content pre-election (CC16_330e) o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA403b o Using “oppose” means Outcomes 3 & 4 will be the pro-gun control position, for easier explanation in write-up • Since response options are dichotomous, this is mathematically equivalent to assessing “support” 4) Mean credibility rating of speaker from MIA404a/b. o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA404 5) Mean credibility rating for statement from MIA405a/b. o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA405 Hypotheses - H1: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is consistent with party platform policy position of the party of the speaker o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. - H1C1: Persuasiveness/credibility of party-consistent statement will differ when speaker is leader of Democrats rather than leader of Republicans o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for H1C1 but test it to be thorough. - H1C2: Persuasiveness/credibility of party-contrary statement will differ when speaker is leader of Democrats rather than leader of Republicans o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for H1C2 but test it to be thorough. - H2a: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is consistent with the pre-test position of the respondent on gun policy. o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. o Reason/implication: Motivated reasoning (note that we can’t distinguish between a positive effect from pro-attitudinal information or counter-arguing from counter-attitudinal information) - H2b: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is the same as pre-test position of respondent and statement is consistent with party platform policy position of the party of the speaker (interaction = H1 x H2) o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. o Reason/implication: ignore even pro-attitudinal voice if it is an intra-party policy maverick. No credit to opposing party → exacerbates partisan stereotypes/division/polarization. - H2C1 & H2C2: Same as for H1 above, but for respondent-consistent and respondent-contrary o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for corollaries but test it to be thorough. - H3a: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when party affiliation of respondent is the same as the party of the speaker. o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. o Reason/implication: Following party cue hueristic - H3b: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when speaker is of same party as respondent and statement is consistent with party platform policy position of the party of the speaker (interaction = H1 x H3) o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. o Reason/implication: ignore co-partisan voice if it is an intra-party policy maverick. Ignore intra-party debate. - H3C1 & H3C2: Same as for H1 above, but for party agreement between speaker and respondent o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for corollaries but test it to be thorough. - H4a: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is consistent with pre-test position of respondent and from a speaker from same party (interaction = H2 x H3) o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o Reason/implication: tuning out all dissonant voices: Partisanship blinds people to policy allies. Prior opinion leads people to ignore inter-party debate. - H4b: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is the same as pre-test position of respondent and speaker is of same party as respondent and statement is consistent with party platform policy position of the party of the speaker (interaction = H1 x H2 x H3) o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o Reason/implication: Total echo chamber – only listening to voices that are giving expected message that the respondent already agrees with. • Worst-case scenario for deliberative democracy ideal. Pure confirmation. - H4C1 & H4C2: Same as for H1 above, but for multiple interactions o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for corollaries but test it to be thorough. Heterogeneity: - By self-reported political engagement index: high/low split at median o Expectation: larger effect among high engagement - By correct factual knowledge index: high/low split at median o Expectation: larger effect among high engagement - By Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence index of laws: restrictive/permissive split at median o Expectation: larger effect among high engagement

q17.value: Regression of post treatment measures on dummies for treatment conditions, with one condition omitted as the reference point since there is no untreated control group in this experiment. All regressions will also include a series of covariates from the CCES (detailed in the pre-analysis plan). Heterogeneous treatment effects will be tested using interactions of relevant covariates and treatment indicators. Analysis relies on full assumptions of the Rubin-Neyman model. One-sided hypothesis testing will be used for hypotheses with a clear directional expectation.

q27.value: YouGov on behalf of the Cooperative Congressional Election Study

registration_responses.q1: Party Persuasion about Gun Policy (Exp. 2 - 2016 CCES Survey Experiments)
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: This survey experiment tests the influence of US Congressional party leaders on attitudes about gun regulation policy. The treatments use hypothetical statements from the Democratic and Republican leaders of the US Senate with randomly assigned elements to test the influence of partisan affiliation and gun regulation policy positions that are consistent with or contrary to the Republican and Democratic parties. The survey experiment is embedded in the post-election wave of the University of Miami module of the 2016 Cooperative Congressional Election Study.
registration_responses.q16: Outcomes 1) Reduction in gun related deaths – two outcomes with opposing policy pre-disposition phrasing a) Pro-regulation phrasing: stricter laws lead to fewer deaths i) Mean on four point response scale (omit skip, not asked) ii) Dummy for Big (1) or Some (2) reduction in deaths (Big/Some = 1; Little/No = 0) b) Pro-ownership phrasing: more ownership leads to fewer deaths i) Mean on four point response scale (omit skip, not asked) ii) Dummy for Big (1) or Some (2) reduction in deaths (Big/Some = 1; Little/No = 0) c) Note: this was supposed to be a pre-post difference measure… but I screwed up the instructions to YouGov so the pre-question and post-question were independently randomly assigned. i) Pre-test was the beginning of the pre-election wave ii) Since the questions have different valences, pre-post is only possible for half of each experiment, and therefore dropped 2) Universal background checks a) Dummy for “support” in MIA403a (dichotomous choice = support/oppose) b) Change from Common Content pre-election (CC16_330a) o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA403a 3) Easy concealed carry permit a) Dummy for “oppose” in MIA403b (dichotomous choice = support/oppose) o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA403b b) Change from Common Content pre-election (CC16_330e) o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA403b o Using “oppose” means Outcomes 3 & 4 will be the pro-gun control position, for easier explanation in write-up • Since response options are dichotomous, this is mathematically equivalent to assessing “support” 4) Mean credibility rating of speaker from MIA404a/b. o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA404 5) Mean credibility rating for statement from MIA405a/b. o Omit non-response (skipped, not asked) in MIA405 Hypotheses - H1: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is consistent with party platform policy position of the party of the speaker o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. - H1C1: Persuasiveness/credibility of party-consistent statement will differ when speaker is leader of Democrats rather than leader of Republicans o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for H1C1 but test it to be thorough. - H1C2: Persuasiveness/credibility of party-contrary statement will differ when speaker is leader of Democrats rather than leader of Republicans o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for H1C2 but test it to be thorough. - H2a: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is consistent with the pre-test position of the respondent on gun policy. o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. o Reason/implication: Motivated reasoning (note that we can’t distinguish between a positive effect from pro-attitudinal information or counter-arguing from counter-attitudinal information) - H2b: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is the same as pre-test position of respondent and statement is consistent with party platform policy position of the party of the speaker (interaction = H1 x H2) o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. o Reason/implication: ignore even pro-attitudinal voice if it is an intra-party policy maverick. No credit to opposing party → exacerbates partisan stereotypes/division/polarization. - H2C1 & H2C2: Same as for H1 above, but for respondent-consistent and respondent-contrary o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for corollaries but test it to be thorough. - H3a: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when party affiliation of respondent is the same as the party of the speaker. o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. o Reason/implication: Following party cue hueristic - H3b: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when speaker is of same party as respondent and statement is consistent with party platform policy position of the party of the speaker (interaction = H1 x H3) o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o One-sided hypothesis, but use more conservative two-sided hypothesis test. o Reason/implication: ignore co-partisan voice if it is an intra-party policy maverick. Ignore intra-party debate. - H3C1 & H3C2: Same as for H1 above, but for party agreement between speaker and respondent o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for corollaries but test it to be thorough. - H4a: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is consistent with pre-test position of respondent and from a speaker from same party (interaction = H2 x H3) o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o Reason/implication: tuning out all dissonant voices: Partisanship blinds people to policy allies. Prior opinion leads people to ignore inter-party debate. - H4b: Statement will be more persuasive/credible when statement is the same as pre-test position of respondent and speaker is of same party as respondent and statement is consistent with party platform policy position of the party of the speaker (interaction = H1 x H2 x H3) o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o Reason/implication: Total echo chamber – only listening to voices that are giving expected message that the respondent already agrees with. • Worst-case scenario for deliberative democracy ideal. Pure confirmation. - H4C1 & H4C2: Same as for H1 above, but for multiple interactions o H0: No difference in persuasiveness/credibility o No expectation of support for corollaries but test it to be thorough. Heterogeneity: - By self-reported political engagement index: high/low split at median o Expectation: larger effect among high engagement - By correct factual knowledge index: high/low split at median o Expectation: larger effect among high engagement - By Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence index of laws: restrictive/permissive split at median o Expectation: larger effect among high engagement

All regressions will also include a series of covariates from the CCES (detailed in the pre-analysis plan). Heterogeneous treatment effects will be tested using interactions of relevant covariates and treatment indicators. Analysis relies on full assumptions of the Rubin-Neyman model. One-sided hypothesis testing will be used for hypotheses with a clear directional expectation.

attributes.title: Refugees and Native Reactions in Germany

q1.value: Refugees and Native Reactions in Germany

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Thanks to decades of sustained immigration, European countries have become increasingly diverse. The recent refugee influx is adding to this diversity, and, in doing so, is challenging peaceful co-existence as well as political stability. Our study aims to analyze how immigration and diversity influence the political behavior of the native population. We will investigate party preferences; support for immigrants, diversity and globalization; as well as how these dimensions influence one another. We are conducting a panel study consisting of 6 to 8 waves. Though we have several guiding hypotheses (see below), we expect that the results of each wave will influence the design of the next wave. As such, this pre-registration lays out basic hypotheses only.

q16.value: We are currently asking a series of questions, including whether exposure to refugees is associated with: A. A backlash or greater acceptance; B. Political behavior: left-right ideology; partisanship; voting intentions; nationalism C. Evaluation of one’s local government and local conditions; including neighborhoods, crime rates, property values and the desire to move. Examining the determinants of normatively desirable (or undesirable) outcomes will be a tremendous asset to current policy and scholarly debates. Furthermore, in addition to its importance for understanding the integration of immigrants and refugees, the study offers methodological advantages. Most existing work on the effects of diversity on attitudes is cross-sectional in nature, capturing a snapshot in time. Though valuable, these studies cannot disentangle, for example, whether more tolerant individuals prefer to live in diverse neighborhoods or, alternatively, whether diversity fosters tolerance. By examining how the unexpected (and often random) settlement of refugees alters the views of the same individuals over time, we can get a better handle on how ethnic diversity and, in particular, the ways in which refugees are being settled, shape attitudes and behaviors. We are currently identifying refugee registration centers in Germany and determining settlement patterns. One goal of this project is to compare districts that receive a high number of refugees to those that receive relatively fewer refugees, holding other covariates (such as income and unemployment rates and pre-existing levels of ethnic diversity) relatively constant. We are also collecting data on macro-level characteristics of each district. These data include, for example, property values, quality of public education, crime rates, economic indicators, and patterns of movement and resettlement by the host population. Another, related goal, is to examine how ethnic diversity and globalization are influencing party preferences and the party system. Core Hypotheses: A. General Hypotheses: Economic Threat: We will test whether (controlling for conventional covariates): • Reactions towards refugees and party preferences are a function of both personal and local socio-economic conditions. • Differences in overall standards of living (real and perceived) will be associated with differences in attitudes towards refugees, support for hate crimes, party preferences. Cultural Threat: • Our study will also examine views about Muslims in Germany. Here, one core test will be whether the perception of illiberal orientations among Muslims will elicit more hostile reactions towards Muslims and a shift towards anti-immigrant parties. B. Heterogeneous Effects: • We will pay specific attention to socio-economic and local economic conditions (at the district and at the individual level) as moderating factors. • We will also pay attention to respondents’ levels of tolerance, apathy and empathy as well as commitment to liberal values. • We will pay attention to partisanship and prior voter preferences (on core issues).

q17.value: • We are collecting individual-level data with our panel study • We are also collecting district-level covariates • We have designed vignettes to “manipulate” hypothetical situations that affect individual/local economic conditions with the expectation that this will directly influence levels of support for hate crimes and right-wing parties, like the AFD. • We have developed a list experiment to get at support for hate crimes and other hostile acts. • We will also design vignettes to manipulate Muslim commitments to liberal values and test whether this variation matters in shaping non-Muslim party preferences and attitudes towards Muslims.

q19.value: We anticipate a panel study that ends with 1500 participants. We conducted our first wave in October 2016 (N=3500) and our second wave was conducted in January 2017 (N=3000). Due to attrition our sample sizes will decrease across time.

attributes.title: Ethnic Bias in Urban and Rural Africa

q1.value: Ethnic Bias in Urban and Rural Africa

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The principal goal of the project is to investigate whether ethnic bias (defined as differential altruism toward coethnics and non-coethnics) differs across urban and rural residents in Kenya. The project follows up on the results reported in Berge et al (Forthcoming), which investigates ethnic bias among residents of Nairobi and finds no evidence of bias—except among subjects who had lived in Nairobi for fewer than ten years. These findings suggest that, contrary to the expectations of modernization theory (e.g., Bates 1983; Young 1976), urban residence may dampen rather than heighten ethnic bias. A key implication is that we should see differences in the levels of ethnic bias across urban and rural samples. The project also test whether such differences are also apparent in the Affect Misattribution Procedure, and whether ethnic bias varies across participants who are and are not primed to the threat of electoral violence.

q16.value: The main hypotheses to be tested are that patterns of play in the Dictator, Public Goods, and Choose-Your-Dictator games will vary across coethnic and non-coethnic partners, and that these differences will vary across participants recruited from urban and rural settings.

q27.value: Researchers and the Busara Center for Behavioral Economics
